target_title: encoding is interpreted wrongly
encoding is interpreted wrongly

note.body:
Hrmm, even when I try to open this with gedit it will fail to load completely due to an invalid byte sequence.

What that tells me is that if we are to deal with this, it has to be dealt with in GtkSourceView directly.

The workaround, at least for now, since this isn't actually valid in any encoding, is that you use the open dialog and select `UTF-8` instead of `Automatically Detect`.

You'll still get the fallback conversion for the invalid UTF-8 byte sequence, but at least you can open/edit it.

It's unlikely that I'll have time to look into this further, but if someone wants to, I would dive into `gtksourceview/gtksourcebufferoutputstream.c` to locate the bits that automatically discover encoding.

Add  function to check for empty documents
consider a shorter binary name

note.body:
I'm just going to chime in, for the record (maybe there's a better place for this discussion?).

I'm not going to question the gnome binary naming convention, as it makes perfect sense for apps that are launched from the gnome desktop environment, and `gnome-text-editor` is a fine name for the default gnome text editor.

That said there is a reason why popular text editors have short CLI names (vi, code, gedit, emacs, nano/pico, subl, zed, xed, etc), and that is that you tend to type them *alot* in the terminal.

I'm usually on Ubuntu (for instance we use Ubuntu as the main OS at work), and gedit was always my goto editor for random command line workflows in desktop sessions (vim in ssh sessions). With Ubuntu 24.04 the default editor switched to gnome-text-editor (I really like it BTW), but it has been quite annoying from a command line UX point-of-view (tab completion is horrible, for instance).

The obvious solution is to add an alias in my .bashrc or to add a symlink, and I have done that on some machines (e.g. on one machine I added "alias gedit=gnome-text-editor"), but that has a number of issues:

* You have to do it on every machine and every user.
* What should the alias be called? There is no blessed gnome convention. Alias naming is hard as we're in a super-global namespace and short name conflicts are very likely.
* When you move to someone else's machine or log in as a different user you don't know if that person has an alias or what that alias is.

Thus I would suggest that at least some thought is given to this UX problem. I would hope to see:

* At a minimum a blessed shorthand name (gt? ged? gte? ...) that has some thought behind it (no name collisions, easy/quick to type on a qwerty keyboard, tab-completion?, etc).
* Preferably also a deployment of the shorthand name (this could e.g. be a symlink or a thin CLI wrapper tool) that comes with the default installation of gnome + gnome-text-editor.

Just my two cents. Thanks for a great tool!

target_title: "Document Type" window is not closable with ESC key

note.body:
I was able to reproduce this issue from the source code.

As per my understanding, this is happening because of the search-bar at the top of the window. The search bar auto-focuses as the window mounts, and all the keyboard events go to the search bar, thus `ESC` gets ignored.

To confirm, I tried removing the search bar from that popup window temporarily, by setting `search-mode-enabled` to `False`:
```xml
<!-- file: editor-language-dialog.ui -->
...
          <object class="GtkSearchBar">
            <property name="search-mode-enabled">False</property>
...
```

with the above change, the window correctly closes on pressing `ESC`. 

@chergert Please let me know if I've got it right.

target_title: excessive spellchecking errors

note.body:
![image](/uploads/89f01006aba53e4bdb301c8a380e0f7a/image.png)

In this case, it looks like it's trying to do word breaking using en_US PangoLanguage and not zh_TW. That would be our first thing to fix. If there is no selected dictionary, it just always assumes the word exists.

So lets start by making that machinery work as designed.

target_title: excessive spellchecking errors

note.body: I'll add some plumbing for this, and we can tweak initial enabled state based on that.

target_title: excessive spellchecking errors

note.body:
> Personally I think it would also be better to make spellchecking opt-in for users - that would be a simpler cleaner default IMO.

Absolutely not going to happen.

target_title: excessive spellchecking errors

note.body:
> Also since only the current locale language is checked: multilingual text will also get flagged.

I've been asking for about 4 years now how people want to handle this, but nobody has had a good answer for me. We can make hybrid dictionaries, but what I've heard from people is that is not desired either.

So realistically that leaves two directions:

 * Punt this stuff off to LLMs (which the new ABI should at least allow for us to do)
 * Continue to make this a configuration issue on the client system, since they can control which backends are used.

Note that we do not use hunspell directly, it's all through enchant. So it really comes down to how enchant is configured. Having a functional dictionary is absolutely part of localization and outreach to communities, and is probably a larger problem (distro, governments, etc) than what I can provide here.

target_title: excessive spellchecking errors

note.body:
Spell checking can be disabled globally through the View Options (document wrench icon button in the header bar).

That said, it would be useful if Text Editor would gray out spell checking itself if for the current language there is no dictionary available. I think in enchant that can be checked with `dict_exists`. I don't know libspelling well but I think it doesn't support similar?

push_data.commit_title: view: override extend_selection for source view

target_title: App freezes when double clicking a word to select it

note.body:
So a bit about what fundamentally is going wrong that has to be improved (in probably both GTK and GtkSourceView).

Currently, this is all mucked up because GtkSourceView has to care about "invisible" characters even though we don't use them at all in Text Editor.

Combining that (which uses some extremely slow API in GTK/Pango) with needing to walk forwards/backwards to extend the selection in two-manners exacerbates the problem.

For example, when trying to extend the selection backwards, it tries to create an upper boundary on how far back to look. That is done by looking at "full word" which is basically any non-space character (like E in vim).

Since this is minified JSON here, that means it ends up looking at ever character back to the start, and in the extra slow fashion for visible char checks.

It then does the same for the boundary at the ends (leading to the end of the minified file).

Then it looks for extra natural character boundaries (which are basically your locale's break points plus `_` or something like that) in both directions, ensuring the closer of the full and extra-natural positions.

If there was API in GTK to move by visible characters (and it was fast) we could possibly use that in GtkSourceView to do this faster. But there isn't, and calculating that is extremely difficult given how the B+Tree in GtkTextBTree is implemented for line segments and visiblity tags.

I still don't get why I can get situations where I close a tab, reopen it, and it becomes fast again, but I think that is related to the tag table being created in such a way that some shortcuts can be taken. It also looks like `find_by_log_attrs()` is much faster in some cases, only needing to tweak the offset position of the iter vs full calculation in the slow cases. Again, not sure _why_ that happens yet.

The easiest stop gap for us might be to just implement `extend_selection` in Text Editor and ignore all the invisible stuff since we don't even use it.

It has a comment about needing better API here, and that is probably true.

target_title: Add  function to check for empty documents

note.body:
I think having a function to check if the page is empty is a fine thing to add (especially if we can make use of it).

But I'm not sure about the policy change in `_editor_window_request_close_pages()`.

It appears to ignore pages if they've been modified, but are now empty. That modified bit will be re-applied when restoring state. But it is also set if the user changes the buffer (say an accidental keyboard/touchpad buffer change).

I think we need a way to differentiate between these two cases and only ignore the buffer in the first case.

Editor prevents sleep if there are any unsaved files open
text editor doesn't notice changed files
Editor prevents sleep if there are any unsaved files open

note.body:
This works correctly on GNOME, so the problem exists between GTK and whatever KDE is providing. Either because KDE isn't providing the appropriate API or GTK needs to learn it (or some other bug in-between).

The API is absolutely clear on the use as far as we're concerned in the application side, so as far as Text Editor is concerned, it's doing the right thing.

```c
/**
 * GtkApplicationInhibitFlags:
 * @GTK_APPLICATION_INHIBIT_LOGOUT: Inhibit ending the user session
 *   by logging out or by shutting down the computer
 *...
 */
```

Looking at `gtk_application_impl_dbus_startup()` in GTK's `gtk/gtkapplication-dbus.c` shows where the session-manager proxies are created. I see session-manager proxies created for `org.gnome.SessionManager` and `org.xfce.SessionManager`. If those fail it looks like it uses the desktop portal.

`gtk_application_impl_dbus_inhibit()` contains the implementation that first tries to use the `SessionManager` proxy when available (so again, GNOME/XFCE have those). If those don't exist, it falls back to the desktop portal implementation.

Given you're on KDE, I suspect that the portal is what is being used, but I don't have an installation at hand that would allow me to verify if they've implemented the other named-endpoints on the D-Bus.

I would say the next two questions to answer on your end are:

 1. Does KDE implement `org.gnome.SessionManager` (you might be able to peek at that with https://flathub.org/apps/org.gnome.dspy while running KDE.
 2. If not, what is the desktop portal implementation used, and find the code specifically for portal implementation. The bug might exist there in handling the different type of inhibits correctly.

Looking at https://github.com/KDE/xdg-desktop-portal-kde/blob/master/src/inhibit.cpp doesn't show any specific handling of logout inhibition though.

Either way, I don't think the issue exists in the areas I can control, so closing.

target_title: Editor prevents sleep if there are any unsaved files open

note.body:
It does indeed inhibit sleep on my machine.

Relevant software versions:
- Text Editor 47.0 (47.0)
- GTK: 4.16.3 (Compiled against 4.16.1)
- GtkSourceView: 5.14.1 (Compiled against 5.13.1)

- Debian unstable with KDE 5.27
- Systemd 256.7-2

Although I will note that I first noticed this issue ~1 year ago, so it's unlikely to have cropped up in the most recent software versions.

I will try and narrow down whether the issue exists in GTK 3 apps and in GNOME later.

target_title: text editor doesn't notice changed files

note.body:
With "the current main branch", I mean that I compiled from source myself (using GNOME Builder if that matters).

Here's how I reproduce it (simplified to not using vim, because it does not matter):

1. In Text Editor, create a new file with a single line saying "foo".
2. Save it as "~/test.txt"
3. Switch to a terminal
4. run `echo "bar" >> ~/test.txt`
5. Switch back to Text Editor

I see no notice in Text Editor. Switching to nano makes no difference. Deleting and creating a new one also does not show any notice, neither does moving or copying another file onto it. So no, it's clearly not a matter of how I modify the file.

So clearly, something is not working with change-detection on my system. I'm running Debian testing, with all packages up to date. I've been experiencing the issue for as long as I've been using Text Editor, which is several months at least.

I do believe that GNOME Builder also uses flatpaks, though. So perhaps this is a flatpak-related issue?

target_title: text editor doesn't notice changed files

note.body:
With "the current main branch" do you mean the flatpak from GNOME Nightly — is the issue specific to flatpak?

I can't reproduce the issue with native package of Text Editor 47.1 on Arch Linux:
1. Editing the file with `nano`, Text Editor shows the notice 
2. Also if I edit it a 2nd time with `nano`
3. Same if I delete the file and create it anew, Text Editor shows the notice
4. And if I overwrite the file with another file, Text Editor shows the notice

I can't imagine vim does it differently that either of those 3 methods.

Which OS are you using?

target_title: Editor prevents sleep if there are any unsaved files open
`CTRL+BACKSPACE` only deletes a single character at a time, instead of whole words

note.body:
I would make sure you test with `gtk4-demo --run=textview` (in `gtk4-devel-tools` on Fedora) and see if you can replicate.

It is extremely unlikely the issue is in Text Editor and more likely a layer below it.

There is a small amount of backspace handling in GtkSourceView, so if things work with `gtk4-demo`, then the next step is to build gtksourceview from `master` and run `./tests/test-widget` to see if you can replicate there.

Allow tabs bar always visible
Allow tabs bar always visible

note.body:
I don't think I want to use the displaying of tabs as a band-aid over hiding sensitive information.

So on it's surface, I'd say this is a nak from me on implementing.

However, if you feel strongly about it, you can create an issue in whiteboards (see https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-text-editor/-/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md?ref_type=heads#design-first in our contributors guide) and work through the design implications of such a change.

target_title: Allow tabs bar always visible

note.body:
I use Text editor to take quick notes and I also have "restore session" active. Sometimes I have pasted "confidential" text I forget to discard or even passwords, and when I open text editor again the password is also in the title, so I have to open a new tab, then close the old one.. 

In summary, it is not a problem, it is a very nice to have option just for "convenience" and besides, I like tabs. 

In my defense, I said it was an odd request.

target_title: Allow tabs bar always visible

note.body: Which underlying problem would that solve?

note.body: I left some saved documents open and then closed Text Editor. When I opened the app again, the previous documents were there, but the clear history button was still grayed out. Same thing with the main branch and with 47.1.

target_title: editor-preferences-dialog: Some UI tweaks to the "Behavior" section

note.body:
Heh, I didn't know about this button. 

What does this button actually do? It's got a destructive styling implying an irreversible action but it lacks context/information IMO. 

Does it only clear the list of documents that appears in the Open popover? If so, seems like putting that action in that popover might contextualize it better.

If it's to stay in the Preferences window, I'm inclined to suggest having a button row, as proposed in this MR, that says something like "Clear Document History" to clear up some ambiguity. Might also be worth considering dropping the destructive style, if it's just pruning things.

target_title: editor-preferences-dialog: Some UI tweaks to the "Behavior" section

note.body: I'd prefer specifying which history is being removed.

target_title: editor-preferences-dialog: Some UI tweaks to the "Behavior" section

note.body: Clearing history will not clear anything with drafts or that is modified to avoid loosing data. Particularly in the presence of a crash (e.g. kill).

target_title: editor-preferences-dialog: Some UI tweaks to the "Behavior" section

note.body: Does the clear history work properly in a toolbox? Even with the `main` branch I can't get it to work. I create some documents and then I kill the gnome-text-editor process; the documents get restored but the button remains insensitive.

target_title: editor-preferences-dialog: Some UI tweaks to the "Behavior" section

note.body: @snwh @monster WDYT?

Segfault on printing (vers. 47.1)

note.body:
It works fine for me on Arch Linux in Gnome Shell on Wayland.

Does it maybe not happen when you start it like this:
```sh
env GSK_RENDERER=ngl gnome-text-editor
```
I was going to suggest to try printing from different GTK 4 app, as I think what you're showing is an issue with the GTK print dialog — not Text Editor itself — but I don't readily know of any. There's Papers (the new document viewer) on Flathub if you would try: https://flathub.org/apps/org.gnome.Papers

Also please add a stack trace. Make sure you already have `debuginfod` installed or else install it, log out and back in to activate, then run `coredumpctl gdb` to start the debugger for the most recent crash. Then it should suffice to enter the commands:
```
set pagination off
set logging enabled on
thread apply all backtrace full
quit
```
That saves the stack trace to a gdb.txt file in your home directory.

target_title: Segfault on printing (vers. 47.1)

Spell check fails to work after second level indent in Markdown

note.body:
Please don't re-open bugs unless you've read the resolution.

> After peeking at `markdown.lang` this appears to be intended behavior.

8 spaces or two tab indentation is a code block according to the GtkSourceView language-spec, not bullets, and therefore, not a candidate for spellcheck.

note.body:

We want to open it wherever we can actually save. But again, this is all way beneath our abstractions and mostly broken by time it gets to us.

target_title: Failed to save a file mounted via SFTP

note.body: I just realized those are two different paths. Sorry about that. But wouldn't it be better to have text editor open network shares directly inside the `/run/user/1000/gvfs` subdirectories?

target_title: Failed to save a file mounted via SFTP

note.body:
It does not. When opening via Open File dialog it will get redirected to /run/user again.

This is really strange. I stumbled upon this issue today when I wanted to manage files on my server. Text Editor installed via flatpak cannot save the file **but when opening with Vim** (installed via package manager) and navigating to the location `/run/user/1000/gvfs/sftp:host=...` can save file normally.

(Tested on Text Editor version 47.0 from Flathub)

target_title: home key doesn't take you all the way to the start

note.body:
The visible area as far as the textview is concerned is the whole area. And since you don't have text wrapping, it thinks that is the minimal distance necessary to perform the movement.

If someone finds themselves interested to work on this, I suggest overriding the smart-home behavior from GtkSourceView and use an alternate "visible rect" to determine where to clamp to.

Builder does this, but it is a bit of a rats nest because you need to basically ignore everything in GtkTextView as far as movements, and the tail of cases to handle is pretty long.

metainfo: Expand and modernize

note.body: Probably compat issues with older AppStream versions, since the suffix *used* to be required for apps before it was deprecated when we got `<launchable>` for associating the metainfo with a desktop file. New apps generally do not make this accomodation; neither Loupe nor Snapshot does, for instance.

target_title: Context Menu opened from minimap is pixelated
Memory leak reported when closing file

note.body:
The first file just contains a bunch of `Conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s)` which which are almost certainly caused by Valgrind's inability to handle JIT well (and all the syntax highlighting regex are JIT).

The second one, without a suppression file, is utterly overwhelming to the point I'm not going to invest time in this.

However, from what I did scan it looks pretty normal. All sorts of global state "leaks" and that isn't a problem. The GPU shader compilers leak, the svg renderer leaks, the parsed syntax files leak, glyph caches leak, spellcheck dictionaries leak, GObject type system leaks,

target_title: Memory leak reported when closing file
Memory leak reported when closing file
